document.docTitle: Rugabinthus newguineae Tan & Robillard 2022, comb. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Rugabinthus, a new genus of Lebinthina (Orthoptera, Gryllidae, Eneopterinae) from New Guinea

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Rugabinthus, a new genus of Lebinthina (Orthoptera, Gryllidae, Eneopterinae) from New Guinea

mods:name.mods:affiliation: Institut de Systematique, Evolution, Biodiversite (ISYEB), Museum national d'Histoire naturelle, CNRS, SU, EPHE, UA, 57 rue Cuvier, CP 50, 75231 Paris Cedex 05, France.

Malagufuk (https: // www. inaturalist. org / observations / 72638321). Photo credit: Benoit Segerer.

subSubSection.paragraph: Larandopsis newguineae Bhowmik, 1981[1979]: 39 - Desutter-Grandcolas and Jaiswara 2012 : 31, according to Bhowmik's descriptions and illustrations belonging to Lebinthus [but not moved to Lebinthus ] - Cigliano et al. 2021 ( Orthoptera Species Files Online).

materialsCitation.collectorName: Bhowmik, H. K. Bhowmik, L. E. Cheesman

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Holotype
: INDONESIA • ♀ ; Dutch New Guinea : Cyclops Mts , Sabron Camp 2;
2000 ft
; July 1936 ; identified
Larandopsis newguineae
Bhowmik by H. K. Bhowmik , 1973; L. E. Cheesman leg; BMNH-1936-271.

subSubSection.paragraph:
INDONESIA • 1♀ ; N. New Guinea , "Boven-Jemomaissin" ca.
400 m
; 4 April 1911 ; molecular sample L199; Dr P. N. v. Kampen , Ned. Nw. Guinea Exp leg; RMNH
• 1♀ ; N. New Guinea; 1911; Dr P. N. v. Kampen, Ned. Nw. Guinea Exp leg; RMNH • 1♀ ; N. New Guinea; April-May 1911; Dr P. N. v. Kampen, Ned. Nw. Guinea Exp leg; RMNH.

Among congeners,
R. newguineae
comb. nov. is characterized by its large size, FWs not reaching abdomen mid-length but well developed, coloration homogeneously dark brown, and very long ovipositor.

This species is known only by female specimens until now, which makes it difficult to place it in a genus among the Lebinthina because several genera share the same general shape, such as
Rugabinthus
and
Macrobinthus
, while being mostly characterized by male characters (FW venation and genitalia). A molecular phylogenetic study in preparation revealed that this species belongs to the clade corresponding to
Rugabinthus
, justifying the new combination proposed here.
